sols_html:
To determine the intervals of concavity, we must evaluate \(f''(x)\) and determine where it is positive and negative:

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{4}{\pi}\tan^{-1}(x) & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\ 2 - x^{4} & \text{if } x < 1 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

Evaluating the second derivative of f gives

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{4}{\pi}\frac{-2x}{(1 + x^{2})^{2}} & \text{if } x > 1 \\ -12x^{2} & \text{if } x < 1 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

From this we see that the possible inflection points are x = 0. We need only confirm that the sign of the concavity changes across x = 0. We must also consider concavity changes across x = 1 since \(f\) is not differentiable there.

When x < 1, the second derivative is always negative since -12x2 is always negative.

When x > 1, the second derivative is always negative as well since in that case, -2x is always negative.

From these results we can see that \(f(x)\) is concave down for all x except at the critical points. In other words, \(f(x)\) is concave down on \((-\infty,0),(0,1),(1,\infty)\) and so, there are no inflection points.
